text: hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review villagers away land
villagers is the musical project of
singer songwriter and guitarist Connor J
O'Brien whose music early in the
inception of villagers moved me quite a
bit in 2009 through the hollow kind EP
on the CP it's just a nice handful of
downtrodden songs of sadness tracks like
the meaning of the ritual and then
pieces
certainly showcased a huge bright eyes
slash Elliott Smith influence they are
songs that O'Brien strung together
shortly after the demise of his previous
band the immediate I hadn't heard
anything from the band in a little while
and then the announcement came that in
2010 villagers would be signing on with
Domino Records and releasing its first
full-length LP the album which was
eventually dropped was titled becoming a
jackal it made it to number one on the
Irish indie charts
it was Mercury Prize nominated as well
but still this full-length didn't really
resonate with me in the same way that
the EP that preceded it did the
production was cleaner a lot of the
songs on here were built up with with
just slicker instrumentation but I felt
like the the overall sound of villagers
had become kind of sterile maybe a
little neutered kind of predictable
especially on reworked versions of older
tracks on this new album such as the
meaning of the ritual so I was going
into this new sophomore LP hoping for
more and I definitely feel like I got
that for sure O'Brien
makes some really clear and obvious
attempts to kind of break or move away
from that mole that his first album was
cast in but the recipe may end up
tasting maybe a little funny to people
who have been hardcore fans of the very
short progression that villager's has
undergone so far O'Brien
without a doubt is still a very
captivating singer/songwriter with
lyrics and a lot of emotion and and
maybe for many fans that will be all
that that truly matters at the end of
the day but on this new LP with a lot of
songs here there are a lot of
electronics running in tandem with the
usual mix of guitar bass drums and
vocals in addition to the electronics I
would say more pianos brass and strings
too I think in general villager's is
coming off way more ambitious in the
studio with this release just take a
listen to the hustling and bustling
electronic tones at the beginning of the
track the waves or the glitchy
electronic sequenced percussion on the
song earthly pleasure on top of this
you're getting a lot of instances of
just cascading horn arrangements that
that swell and fall lots and lots of
effects on some tracks villager's is
definitely moving away from its kind of
simple and humble beginnings with just a
lot of sonic flash and while overall I
didn't really end up loving this LP to
death I do admire and much more than
becoming a jackal not only are the songs
really good the production is great but
this LP is definitely the sound of a guy
trying to just add a little bit of spark
to his craft the song the waves which is
one of the main promotional tracks that
came out before this record and a great
one that there's a lot of cute bubbly
electronics at the start of this track
with some moody guitar and vocals kind
of coming up underneath it with some
touches of piano as well that are really
beautiful it's like all of these
synthetic sounds are just sounding
really kind of light and airy inand
sweet on the ears while everything else
is just kind of becoming more and more
sour and I love the way that the vocals
kind of speed up with intensity in the
lyrics the way that they kind of hit
rhythmically as O'Brien delivers them
and I love the way this track just kind
of moves and shifts and builds up from
one section to another with just these
subtle swells of piano organ and horns
just before the chorus kind of kicks in
there's a serious flow to the
instrumentation all over this album
whenever there are some arrangements
involved they're so well played and so
meticulously crafted as the waves
continues the vocals just kind of fall
backwards and kind of like a James Blake
sort of way into this cavernous mountain
of reverb as the electronics kind of get
glitchy ER and then noisier it's just
really apocalyptic huge ending and I
like the way that villagers kind of
builds up toward the end of the song The
Grateful song that's got a really
ambitious ending filled with strings
that yeah it's not really the same mood
as the previous track that I just
mentioned but man is it a thick mood I
mean thick with just this kind of
uplifting soaring head and the clouds
kind of vibe instrumentally at least
there are a few other tracks on here
that I wish kind of went that far like
the introductory track my lighthouse or
passing a message both of which I just
kind of feel like get cut short and sort
of but other tracks on here do a really
great job at embracing sort of a sense
of simplicity and don't leave me hanging
in the process like in a Newfoundland
you are free which is like this
beautiful acoustic track which has sort
of a lullaby quality to it the piano on
this song and the guitar that
occasionally pops in waltz together
really slowly and I love the way they
will Brian sings on this track his voice
just the the tambour of it is a perfect
setting for music this soft his voice
just sounds so endearing on this track
it would have been the perfect ending to
this album I thought but then the rhythm
composer track which kind of seems to be
this singer-songwriters tribute to
percussionists drummers it's it's a
cutesy kind of track maybe a little
corny it feels a little tagged on but
even this track which i think is really
one of the weakest out of the entire
bunches is really not that bad so you do
kind of have these softer lullaby kind
of tracks but O'Brien is equally
comfortable on a song like nothing's
changed which is like this very kind of
mid paced piano rocker a song that is
very slickly produced something that I
feel like the killers would have rocked
back when they were putting out better
tracks and I loved the string kissed
climax on this song the way it just
rises again another moment on this LP
this kind of inspiring
I feel like overall this LP could sir
we have been bolder there are a good
handful of tracks on here that do not
take the adventurous plunge that the
other songs on here do pretty much just
a slight improvement I think for
villagers really giving me hope that
there will be something maybe even
better on the horizon past this album
I'm feeling light 7 to a decent 7 on
this LP but if you've given it a listen
what did you think about it did you love
it hate it why and what do you think I
should review next anthony Fantana
villagers forever
